Contingence Table

Source: R/contingencyTable.R
contingenceTable.Rd

Contingence Table

contingenceTable(input_raster, pixelresolution = 30)

Arguments

input_raster

list (of filenames or Raster* objects), RasterStack(brick) or RasterStack(stack)
pixelresolution

numeric. The pixel resolution in meter.

Value

A list that contains 5 objects.

  • lulc_Mulstistep: <tibble> The table of contingency between all step of time analysed, contains 8 columns:

    1. Period: <chr> The period [Yt, Yt+1].

    2. From: <dbl> a category i.

    3. To: <dbl> a category j.

    4. km2: <dbl> The quantity in kilometer that transit from the classes category i to category j in the period [Yt, Yt+1].

    5. Interval: <dbl> The number of time point between the first and the last year of the period [Yt, Yt+1].

    6. QtPixel: <int> The quantity of pixel that transit from the classes category i to category j in the period [Yt, Yt+1].

    7. yearFrom: <chr> The year that the change come from [Yt]

    8. yearTo: <chr> The year that the change go for [Yt+1]

  • lulc_Onestep:<tibble> The table of contingency between the first and the last year analysed [Yt, Yt+1], contains 8 columns like lulc_Mulstistep.

  • tb_legend: <tibble> A table of the pixel value his name and color, contains 3 columns:

    1. classValue: <dbl> the pixel value of the classes of land use

    2. className: <factor> The name or legend associate with a given pixel value, here as factor with a specific level for blablabla

    3. color: <chr> The color associate with the given pixel value. Befor others step of analysis, one would want to change the className and color values. Some details.

      • the class name have to be in the same order of the classValue column, the levels the order that the graphs legend will have to be printed. Like:

        
        myobject$tb_legend$className <- factor(c("name1", "name2", "name3", "name4"),
                                               levels = c("name3", "name2", "name1", "name4"))

      • the color by the same order of the classValue comuln, it can be a colour name (eg. "black") or an HEX value (eg. #FFFFFF). Like:

        
       myobject$tb_legend$color <- c("#CDB79E", "red", "#66CD00", "yellow")

  • totalArea: <tibble> A table of two columns with the total area of study, contains 2 columns:

    1. area_km2: <numeric> The total area of study in square meter.

    2. QtPixel: <numeric> The total area of study in quantity of pixel

  • totalInterval: <numeric> The value represinting the whole time points interval of time analysed [Yt, Yt+1], in years.

Examples


contingenceTable(demo_landscape(year = 2000:2005, res = 1), pixelresolution = 1)
#> $lulc_Multistep
#> # A tibble: 125 x 8
#>    Period     From    To      km2 QtPixel Interval yearFrom yearTo
